title: What are the theories of harmony in the works of St. Bernard and the dating of Dante's journey?
first_phrase: This text explores the concept of harmony of spheres in the works of St. Bernard and its connection with Dante's Divine Comedy. It includes a passage from St. Bernard's Legend of the Terrestrial Paradise and the relevant verses from Dante's Inferno and Purgatory used to date his journey. In the final section, Afrodite Urania and Frater Petrus discuss the verses used to date the dantesque voyage.

last_phrase: In conclusion, Dante's masterpiece, the Divine Comedy, is a timeless work of art that offers unique insights into human nature, morality and redemption. Spanning across three volumes, the Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso, the work is a poetic exploration of the afterlife, which remains as relevant today as it was when it was first written in the 14th century. Through vivid descriptions of landscapes and characters, Dante brings to life a vision of a grand moral universe, in which individuals must navigate the challenges of life to achieve ultimate salvation.
